quoteFirst: While returning from the men on duty, who had gone into the thicket with axes, I saw, from a distance, that our people, taking advantage of the beautiful weather and the calm fair day, had wandered out on the prairie in every direction. It was very early; we halted for the night usually
quoteTime: about five o’clock in the afternoon
quoteLast: , so as to move in the morning at daybreak. Soon I met Miss Morris. I dismounted immediately, and leading my horse by the bridle, approached the young lady, happy that I could be alone with her even for a while.
title: Lillian Morris, and Other Stories
author: Sienkiewicz, Henryk, 1846-1916; Garrett, Edmund H. (Edmund Henry), 1853-1929 [Illustrator]; Curtin, Jeremiah, 1835-1906 [Translator]

quoteLast: our pickets from the extreme front were driven in toward the second line by the enemy's cavalry. Hoskins's Battery opened on them and checked the advance. About 5:30 P.M. the enemy got their batteries in position and opened fire on my line. One battery on my right enfiladed a part of my line."
title:
Two Wars: An Autobiography of General Samuel G. French
Mexican War; War between the States, a Diary; Reconstruction Period, His Experience; Incidents, Reminiscences, etc.
author: French, Samuel Gibbs, 1818-1910

quoteFirst: Foggy weather in the morning. Mr Kittson & I set out at 1/
quoteLast: oclock from Spokane and arrived at the Kettle Falls at 1/2 past 6 in the evening which is good days ride. We had two horses each, we left the ones which we rode in the fore part of the day about half way, though they were not knocked up.
title: The Washington Historical Quarterly, Volume V, 1914
author: Various; Meany, Edmond S. (Edmond Stephen), 1862-1935 [Editor]

quoteFirst: Melanchthon’s story speaks, however, not of the morning at all, but of the time before the “_coena_” (i.e. the principal meal, taken
quoteLast: ), when Luther was presumably no longer fasting.
title: Luther, vol. 3 of 6
author: Grisar, Hartmann, 1845-1932; Dessoulavy, C. L. (Charles Louis) [Editor]; Lamond, E. M. [Translator]

quoteTime: about five o'clock in the afternoon
quoteLast: . They were shewn this time into the kitchen, where they found two or three neighbours and friends with aunt Miriam and Cynthy. The former received them with the same calm simplicity that Mr.
title: Queechy
author: Warner, Susan, 1819-1885

quoteLast: , Dr. Overweg appeared. He had experienced great thirst and fatigue; but, having the assistance of Amankee, he got back safe. He at once confessed his fears for Dr. Barth. I began to think this gentleman must either have gone to Ghât, or that some accident had befallen him.
title:
Narrative of a Mission to Central Africa Performed in the Years 1850-51, Volume 1
Under the Orders and at the Expense of Her Majesty's Government
author: Richardson, James, 1806-1851

quoteFirst: The Kaiser, with some of his aides, arrived by motor car at a tavern at Thielt
quoteLast: Apartments had been reserved for the Emperor. Dinner was ready and his personal baggage had already been deposited in the bedroom prepared for him.
title: Stories and Letters from the Trenches
author: Various

quoteFirst: Each man among us thought of these possible and terrible contingencies as the distance increased between us and the _Leda_--our home amid the icy waste--but none spoke of them _then_; all sang cheerily, and pushed on to overhaul the strange craft; thus
quoteLast: we found ourselves alongside, and all paused to survey her with deep and undefinable emotions of awe in our breasts, for she had evidently been long deserted, and now wore a most chilling and desolate aspect.
title: Jack Manly; His Adventures by Sea and Land
author: Grant, James, 1822-1887

quoteLast: , was now, by the way-bill of the regular Post-coach, irrevocably fixed for my departure. I had still half a day to order my house; from which, for two nights and two days and a half, my breast, its breastwork and palisado, was now, along with my Self, to be withdrawn.
title: Translations from the German (Vol 3 of 3): Tales by Musæus, Tieck, Richter
author: Carlyle, Thomas, 1795-1881; Jean Paul, 1763-1825; Musäus, Johann Karl August, 1735-1787; Tieck, Ludwig, 1773-1853

quoteFirst: It was at Paardeberg on Sunday, 18th February,
quoteLast: We were watching a hill overlooking Osfontein farm-house, when some of the enemy were seen to enter the garden surrounding that house. So an order was given by Second Lieutenant Romilly for No.
title:
War's Brighter Side
The Story of The Friend Newspaper Edited by the Correspondents with Lord Roberts's Forces, March-April, 1900
author: Ralph, Julian, 1853-1903
